title: Six of the best family-friendly attractions near Florida’s Fort Lauderdale cruise terminal
text:
Six of the best family-friendly attractions near Florida’s Fort Lauderdale cruise terminal Six of the best family-friendly attractions near Florida’s Fort Lauderdale cruise terminal MANY Caribbean cruises leave from or call at Fort Lauderdale, known as the Venice of America because of its inland waterways. PUBLISHED: 15:07, Sat, Aug 29, 2015 | UPDATED: 15:28, Sat, Aug 29, 2015 GETTY Take a tour out to the swamps and see alligators and other animals in their right element 
Here are six of the best family-friendly attractions in the Florida tourist must-see: Billie Swamp Safari: Visit the Seminole Indian Big Cypress Reservation ( www.semtribe.com ) for a Swamp Buggy Eco-Tour or Airboat Adventure Tour around some of these 2,200 acres to see native and exotic wildlife. 
There is also a Swamp Critter Show and authentic Seminole arts and crafts. Gator night tours: Sawgrass Recreation Park ( www.evergladestours.com ) offers after-dark airboat tours to spot alligators and other nocturnal wildlife in the Everglades. 
There are plenty of daytime activities and tours too, with wildlife shows where you can get a better understanding of alligators and other animals that live in the swamps . 
Deerfield Beach: Fort Lauderdale has 23 miles of sandy beaches, including Deerfield Beach where you can get free surf, skim board and standup paddleboard lessons when you rent the equipment from Island Watersports ( www.islandwatersports.com ). 
You can also swim and snorkel over coral reef with Tropical Sailing ( www.tropicalsailing.com ) and its catamaran trips. GETTY Or maybe relaxing on the beach with a good book is more your cup of tea 
Tropical paradise: Flamingo Gardens ( www.flamingogardens.org ) is one of Florida’s best attractions: 60 acres of botanical gardens and an Everglades Wildlife Sanctuary where you can see alligators, bobcats, otters, panthers, flamingos and more – all birds and animals that have been injured and can’t be released back into the wild – amid native and subtropical plants. State park: The John U Lloyd Beach State Park ( www.floridastateparks.org ) offers canoeing, boating, surf fishing and swimming from a long sandy beach that is home to loggerhead turtles. 
Each year the beach has around 2,000 turtle nests with 150,000 babies emerging from the sand to reach the sea. Space travel: Just in case you prefer to be inside, the Museum of Discovery and Science ( www.mods.org ) has more than 200 interactive exhibits as well as a genuine otter habitat, the largest Atlantic coral reef in captivity, a hang out for bats and a space exhibit with a simulated trip to the Moon or Mars. 
There is also the biggest IMAX 3D screen in Florida. Related articles
